constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

constellations_other.name: Canopy
constellations_other.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

links.description: The real suburb of St. Kilda was intrinsic to the success of The Secret Life of Us, with the show’s stories given a unique sensibility based on the location. Similarly, Redfern Now follows the lives of people living in the real Sydney suburb of Redfern. Both series also star Deborah Mailman.

end.brief_description: Schichlegruber - Doing the Lambeth Walk is a 1942 short propaganda film by Charles A. Ridley of the UK Ministry of Information. It consists of edited existing footage taken from Leni Riefenstahl’s Triumph of the Will.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

links.description: Hell’s Club is part of a long moving image tradition of remixing and repurposing content to create new meaning and perspectives. One of the first instances was Charles A Ridley’s Schichlegruber - Doing the Lambeth Walk (1941), which ridiculed Nazis by soundtracking their propaganda videos with a jaunty tune.

start.title: Hell's Club
start.brief_description: There is a place where all fictional characters meet. Outside of time, outside of all logic. This place is known as HELL’S CLUB, but this club is not safe.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

end.title: Let's Enhance
end.brief_description: Remastered version of Let’s Enhance (2009) made for the Cut-Up exhibition at the Museum of the Moving Image.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

links.description: While Ridley’s Lambeth Walk had a political point to make, sometimes remixing is done simply for entertainment and to illuminate clichés and tropes, like Duncan Robson’s Let’s Enhance, a supercut of film and TV show characters ‘enhancing’ surveillance footage with non-existent technology.

start.title: The Was
start.brief_description: The Was is a sampladelic trip through the neighborhoods of collective memory. Part experimental film and part music video, it is the collaborative meeting of Australian sample artists Soda_Jerk and The Avalanches.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

end.title: TERROR NULLIUS
end.creator_credit: Soda Jerk
end.material_description: Single channel video, projection, colour and audio
end.brief_description: Part political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a political revenge fable that binds together a documentary impulse with speculative muckraking.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

links.description: Artist duo and remix maestros Soda_Jerk took their penchant for reappropriating iconic cinema characters to new levels in TERROR NULLIUS, their 2018 artwork commissioned by ACMI. Rather than a celebration like ‘The Was’, TERROR NULLIUS is a condemnation of mainstream Australian identity.

results.name: Spectacle
results.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

constellations_primary.name: Spectacle
constellations_primary.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

constellations_primary.name: Rodney King LA Riots
constellations_primary.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape and became what is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet. It was a catalyst for the 1992 LA riots, which has influenced media ever since.

constellations_primary.name: Hell no, we won't go
constellations_primary.description: The cultural, social, psychological and political effects of the Vietnam War have been explored through cinematic classics, musicals and comedies.

start.title: Royal tour of Queen Elizabeth II
start.brief_description: In 1954, huge crowds greeted Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip on her Australian tour, all captured by newsreel camera crews who followed the royals around Australia. Footage was also made into the first Australian colour documentary, The Queen in Australia.

constellations_primary.name: Royalty, royalty, royalty
constellations_primary.description: Fascination with the royal family has persisted over the years, as seen through newsreels, documentaries, films, TV shows, tabloid news and satire.

constellations_other.name: Spectacle

end.title: Melbourne Olympics
end.brief_description: After years of waiting, TV was finally broadcast in Australia – just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, which was aired by all three Melbourne TV stations and was the first Olympic Games outside of Europe and America.

constellations_primary.name: No guts, no glory
constellations_primary.description: TV arrived just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. The Olympics crystallise ideas of nationalism, athletic heroism, and controversy, all of which have been explored through countless features, documentaries and TV shows.

end.title: Vietnam War
end.brief_description: The Vietnam War is known as ‘the television war’. Images from the front nightly entered people’s living rooms through on-the-ground reportage. As the war progressed, public support waned and by 1969 protests were held, which were also televised.

start.title: 'Tank Man' protestor, Tiananmen Square
start.creator_credit: Jeff Widener
start.brief_description: ‘An unknown man stared down a column of tanks the morning after the Chinese government massacred pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989. His fate and identity remain unknown, but the moment – captured on film and smuggled to safety – has become a symbol of defiance.

constellations_primary.name: Uncovering the truth
constellations_primary.description: The images of Tank Man during the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989 were captured by photojournalists and shared around the world. The work of journalists has been key to uncovering abuses of power and are rich material for fictional and factual movies and TV.

end.title: September 11
end.brief_description: The world held its breath as two hijacked planes were crashed into the World Trade Center in New York City on 11 September 2001. TV networks around the world bore witness and millions of people saw the historic event unfold in real time.

constellations_primary.name: Post-9/11
constellations_primary.description: The attacks on the World Trader Center in New York City on September 11 2001 were viewed on live television by audiences around the world. The effects of the attack have been explored across various forms of media.

results.name: Eric Bana

results.name: Ana Kokkinos
results.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
key_work.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

end.title: The Oscars slap
end.creator_credit: Casey Briggs
end.brief_description: There are no winners in this Academy Award moment. Even those who took home Oscars had their achievement overshadowed by Will Smith’s startling assault on Chris Rock. When the internet should’ve been buzzing about Troy Kotsur winning the second Oscar awarded to a Deaf performer, or Jane Campion being only the third woman to win for Best Director, it was instead saturated by hot takes, memes and outrage – either for or against Rock’s joke or Smith’s reaction – in an ongoing feedback loop between broadcaster, viewer and meme-maker, which played out in real time during the ceremony.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos

links.description: When Will Smith assaulted comedian Chris Rock at the 2022 Oscars, Australian meme-makers quickly drew comparisons to the TV adaptation of Tsiolkas’ novel. Ironically, Tsiolkas had just published a piece in The Saturday Paper about Oscar scandals.

links.description: Kiki and Kitty creator Nakkiah Liu is one of the many writers and stars of ABC’s hit Black Comedy, the first Indigenous sketch show since Basically Black (1973). While Black Comedy enjoys mainstream success, Basically Black was censored for being too political.

end.title: Top End Wedding dress
end.creator_credit: Heather Wallace
end.brief_description: Miranda Tapsell didn’t want Lauren in Top End Wedding to look like the stereotypical movie love interest – the star and co-writer of the First Nations rom-com wanted to celebrate Blak beauty. Costume designer Heather Wallace collaborated with Tiwi Designs on this stunning wedding dress, which marries silver-screen glamour with authentic Tiwi Island style. While the cut was influenced by golden era Hollywood gowns, the distinctive pattern and colours were inspired by the Tiwi Islands, where the celebratory wedding scene takes place. As Lauren beams and walks the aisle in an authentic headdress, it’s safe to say Tapsell achieved her dream.

results.name: Warwick Thornton
results.description: Brimming with Shakespearean undertones and pathos, Kaytetye filmmaker Warwick Thornton's debut feature Samson and Delilah is both a universal tale and one intrinsically tied to the experience of First Peoples in Central Australia.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Warwick Thornton
key_work.brief_description: A Kaytetye man born and raised in Alice Springs. A film director, screenwriter and cinematographer, his debut feature film Samson and Delilah won the Caméra d’Or at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival. He also won the Asia Pacific Screen Award for Best Film in 2017 for Sweet Country.

constellations_other.name: The Lumière brothers
constellations_other.description: The Lumière brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

links.description: Warwick Thornton’s acclaimed debut feature film won the Caméra d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival. Interpreted as a response to Kevin Rudd’s apology to the Stolen Generation in 2008, Thornton has said “for the Samson and Delilahs of the world [sorry] doesn’t mean shit.”

end.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, monitor, van, mixed media props, paintings, colour and sound
end.brief_description: Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play ‘Mother Courage and Her Children’ the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

links.description: An element of Samson and Delilah is the teen characters stealing a car to escape their government-controlled community. Movement is also at the heart of his film installation work Mother Courage, which featured an elderly Indigenous woman travelling in a van between galleries, selling her art.

Though the film is visually modern, the bard’s dialogue remains.

constellations_other.description: Shadow play uses light and projection to tell stories – fundamentals that would evolve into cinematography. In the Wayang tradition, gunungan open and close performances and indicate scene changes and the puppets pass across the projection screen in a similar way to a wipe transition.

links.description: At the heart of Samson and Delilah is a teenage romance, similar to Romeo and Juliet. However, despite its confronting themes that explore the conditions and treatment of First Peoples and their communities, it’s an essentially hopeful film, unlike Romeo and Juliet.

links.description: Samson and Delilah’s two leads, Rowan McNamara and Marissa Gibson, are not professional actors. Similarly, the cast of Amman Abbasi’s debut feature Dayveon, a coming-of-age tale in Arkansas, are also non-actors. Both films tell a universal story in a specific location.

results.name: Jill Bilcock
results.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Jill Bilcock
key_work.brief_description: An Australian film editor, a member of the Australian Screen Editors guild, as well as the American Cinema Editors society, who has edited films such as Romeo + Juliet (1996), Moulin Rouge! (2001) and Road to Perdition (2002).

constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

end.brief_description: The piano used in Jane Campion’s award-winning classic dates from 1825–30 and was shipped to the New Zealand from London. Two replicas were made – a lightweight version that could be carried through the bush and one with a steel frame for underwater scenes.

constellations_primary.name: When music speaks
constellations_primary.description: Some characters or moments are expressed more intensely through a musical motif than dialogue or action.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman

links.description: Two years after being nominated for the AFI Award for Best Picture with Chez Nous, Chapman received the Academy Award nomination for Best Picture at the 1994 Oscars, for Jane Campion’s classic The Piano.

end.title: Top of the Lake

end.brief_description: A woman haunted by her past, Detective Robin Griffin, investigates complex and unsettling cases.

constellations_other.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_other.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

links.description: After decades forging an acclaimed career, director Jane Campion returned to New Zealand (where The Piano is set) to make another acclaimed work, the TV series Top of the Lake, a story about a missing young girl and the community’s reaction to her disappearance.

start.title: The Last Days of Chez Nous
start.creator_credit: Jan Chapman
start.brief_description: The story of sisters Vicki and Beth, when Vicki begins an affair with Beth’s intriguing French husband.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman

end.title: Monkey Grip
end.creator_credit: Ken Cameron, Patricia Lovell and Pavilion Films
end.brief_description: Explores the joys and traumas of a group of people living in Melbourne’s inner-city. Revolving around the life of a single mother sharing a communal house, the film portrays the lives of talented and reckless artists who refuse to live by the conventional rules.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: The Last Days of Chez Nous was written by celebrated Australian author Helen Garner. Ten years earlier, Garner’s novel Monkey Grip (1977) was adapted for the screen by director Ken Cameron. It follows a group of young artists through Melbourne share houses in the 1970s.

end.title: Dogs in Space
end.brief_description: Melbourne, Australia 1978. The punk phenomenon is sweeping the country and Dogs In Space, a punk group, are part of it. A ragtag collection of outcasts live in a squat, surviving on a diet of old TV space films, drugs and good music.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: Like Monkey Grip, Dogs in Space is a film that follows the exploits of artists and drug users through share houses and the post-punk music scene in Melbourne, during the same period of the late 1970s. It starred INXS front man Michael Hutchence.

end.creator_credit: Phillip Noyce and Elizabeth Knight
end.brief_description: Phillip Noyce’s Backroads (1977), made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.

links.description: Jan Chapman ran the Filmmaker’s Cinema with her first husband, Phillip Noyce. A filmmaker himself, Noyce’s debut film was Backroads, which starred Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor Gary Foley, who also appeared in Dogs in Space.

links.description: The soundtrack to Monkey Grip was produced by the rock band Divinyls, with lead singer Chrissy Amphlett appearing in a small role in the movie. Eight years after recording the film’s soundtrack, the band released their most popular single ‘I Touch Myself’.

end.title: Bad Boys
end.creator_credit: Michael Bay, Bobbie Read, Don Simpson, Jerry Bruckheimer, Columbia Pictures, Don Simpson/Jerry Bruckheimer Films, Sony Pictures, John Vallone, Doug Richardson, Jim Mulholland, Michael Barrie and George Gallo
end.brief_description: Marcus Burnett is a hen-pecked family man. Mike Lowry is a foot-loose and fancy free ladies’ man. Both are Miami policemen, and both have 72 hours to reclaim a consignment of drugs stolen from under their station’s nose. To complicate matters, in order to get the assistance of the sole witness to a murder, they have to pretend to be each other.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman

links.description: Curiously, the music video for ‘I Touch Myself’ was directed by none other than explosion aficionado Michael Bay. Like many directors, Bay started his career directing music videos. When producers Jerry Bruckheimer and Don Simpson noticed his work, they had him direct his first feature: Bad Boys.
